title: 110_s1506
content: The Beach Protection Act of 2007, also known as the Beach Water Pollution Source Identification and Prevention Act, amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include monitoring, public notification, source tracking, sanitary surveys, and prevention efforts to address beachwater pollution sources. It authorizes appropriations of $60,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2012. Additionally, funding is allocated for the Beaches Environmental Assessment and Coastal Health Act. SEC. 3. Amends the Beaches Environmental Assessment and Coastal Health Act of 2000 by changing the year from 2005 to 2012. SEC. 4. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include all state environmental agencies in preventing beachwater pollution sources. SEC. 5. Addresses the use of rapid testing methods. SEC. 5. USE OF RAPID TESTING METHODS. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the use of rapid testing methods for water quality assessment. Rapid testing method defined as providing results within 2 hours. SEC. 6 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require communication within 24 hours of water quality sample results and includes all state agencies with authority over beachwater pollution prevention. SEC. 7 addresses the content of state and local programs. Section 406(c) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include measures for developing a beachwater pollution source identification program and a publicly accessible database for monitoring beachwater quality. The amendment includes measures for timely closures or advisories for coastal recreation waters when water quality standards for pathogens are not met. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE REVIEW. Section 406(h) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include a compliance review requirement for State and local governments receiving grants under this section. The Administrator must assess compliance with statutory and regulatory requirements annually. State or local governments receiving grants must be assessed annually for compliance with requirements. Noncompliance results in corrective action within one year of notification. State or local governments must comply with grant requirements within one year, or face a reduction in Federal funding to not exceed 50 percent. The Comptroller General of the United States will review activities by the third year after enactment. The Administrator must review activities in the first and second calendar years after enactment and submit a report to Congress.
